ygData.subject: New Journal Paper on Evolving Plastic Neural Networks with Novelty Search
ygData.msgSnippet: Sebastian Risi and I are pleased to announce that our paper, Evolving Plastic Neural Networks with Novelty Search, which is accepted to appear in Adaptive

Subject: New Journal Paper on Evolving Plastic Neural Networks with Novelty Search
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=TG52091rOGnPMOHKNV-BtGGWhx0Qek8guCArQQ-hltVi1sunWiRi

Sebastian Risi and I are pleased to announce that our paper, "Evolving Plas=
tic Neural Networks with Novelty Search," which is accepted to appear in Ad=
aptive Behavior journal, is now available in manuscript form:

http://eplex=
.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2010/risi.ab10.html
Direct Link: http://eplex.cs.u=
cf.edu/papers/risi_ab10.pdf

This paper is a major extension of work first =
reported in our 2009 GECCO paper called, "How Novelty Search Escapes the De=
ceptive Trap of Learning to Learn."  It explores in greater detail and thro=
ugh more experiments how novelty search can help to evolve networks that ad=
apt through synaptic plasticity.  It also includes an extensive analysis of=
 how exactly novelty search exploits the search space more effectively in t=
he T-Maze based on a Sammon's Mapping visualization technique that projects=
 the search space into two dimensions.  Other domains tested include the Do=
uble T-Maze and also the Bee Domain.  We believe this work is helpful to th=
e growing field of evolving plastic ANNs because such experiments are often=
 thwarted by deception, which novelty search can help to mitigate.

In a la=
rger context, this paper adds to the growing body of evidence that novelty =
search often does outperform objective search in nontrivial domains.  Of co=
urse, that does not mean it will always work best, but it does mean that th=
e objective-based paradigm is significantly more brittle than once thought,=
 considering that an approach that does not even know what the objective is=
 so often outperforms it.

ken
